articles.headline: As Jurors Turn to Web, Mistrials Are Popping Up
articles.snippet: The use of BlackBerrys, iPhones, Google and Twitter by jurors is wreaking havoc on trials around the country.
articles.abstract: The use of BlackBerrys, iPhones, Google and Twitter by jurors is wreaking havoc on trials around the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, a juror in a big federal drug trial in Florida admitted to the judge that he had been doing research on the case on the Internet, directly violating the judge’s instructions and centuries of legal rules. But when the judge questioned the rest of the jury, he got an even bigger shock.

articles.headline: Cocaine Trade Helps Rebels Reignite War in Peru
articles.snippet: The military is battling a resurgent group of guerrillas, which has reinvented itself as an illicit drug enterprise.
articles.abstract: The military is battling a resurgent group of guerrillas, which has reinvented itself as an illicit drug enterprise.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANAYRE, Peru — First the soldiers came to Río Seco, a coca-growing village in the lush mountain jungles of southern Peru. “They called us subversives and they opened fire,” said Benedicto Cóndor, 55, a coca farmer. They shot dead four people at close range, including a woman who was five months pregnant, witnesses said. Two children, ages 6 and 1, disappeared and are believed dead.

articles.headline: Mutual Funds Move to Restore Investor Confidence
articles.snippet: The proposals took on added importance in September, when a run on a giant money fund reported a per-share value below a dollar.
articles.abstract: The proposals took on added importance in September, when a run on a giant money fund reported a per-share value below a dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Money market funds would promise investors greater safety, but at the price of lower yields, if regulators agreed to a set of changes that the mutual fund industry’s leaders will release on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Outcry Builds in Washington for Recovery of A.I.G. Bonuses
articles.snippet: Lawmakers from both parties demanded that A.I.G. reverse $165 million in bonuses and promised legislation to reclaim the money, if necessary.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers from both parties demanded that A.I.G. reverse $165 million in bonuses and promised legislation to reclaim the money, if necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bonuses that the American International Group awarded last week were paid to 418 employees and included $33.6 million for 52 people who have left the failed insurance conglomerate, according to the office of the New York attorney general.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Louise Story

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Taliban Strike Into Pakistan
articles.snippet: President Obama and his advisers are considering expanding the war in Pakistan beyond the tribal areas to strike at a different center of Taliban power.
articles.abstract: President Obama and his advisers are considering expanding the war in Pakistan beyond the tribal areas to strike at a different center of Taliban power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his national security advisers are considering expanding the American covert war in Pakistan far beyond the unruly tribal areas to strike at a different center of Taliban power in Baluchistan, where top Taliban leaders are orchestrating attacks into southern Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Buffett Is Unusually Silent on Rating Agencies
articles.snippet: The investor, known for piquant and unsparing criticism of his own performance, has not spoken much on the Moody’s credit rating agency, of which he owns a 20 percent stake.
articles.abstract: The investor, known for piquant and unsparing criticism of his own performance, has not spoken much on the Moody’s credit rating agency, of which he owns a 20 percent stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his annual Berkshire Hathaway letter, Warren E. Buffett recently urged investors to pose tough questions at the shareholders meeting in May. Here is one on the mind of some Buffett watchers: When are you going to fix Moody’s?

articles.headline: A.I.G. Bailout Priorities Are in Critics’ Cross Hairs
articles.snippet: Some are upset over the distribution of almost 30 percent of the bailout funds to foreign companies.
articles.abstract: Some are upset over the distribution of almost 30 percent of the bailout funds to foreign companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day, insurance companies sell policies to homeowners to cover the cost of damage in the case of fire. Why would those companies agree to pay out in full to a policyholder even if a fire had not occurred?

articles.headline: Paying Workers More to Fix Their Own Mess
articles.snippet: Nothing highlights the fiction of performance-based pay as well as retention bonuses, particularly for executives.
articles.abstract: Nothing highlights the fiction of performance-based pay as well as retention bonuses, particularly for executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: We cannot attract and retain the best and the brightest talent to lead and staff the A.I.G. businesses  which are now being operated principally on behalf of American taxpayers  if employees believe their compensation is subject to continued and arbitrary adjustment by the U.S. Treasury.

articles.headline: Obama Tries to Draw Up an Inclusive Energy Plan
articles.snippet: The administration is caught between oil companies, that want to expand drilling, and environmental groups, which ask for a ban to be reinstated.
articles.abstract: The administration is caught between oil companies, that want to expand drilling, and environmental groups, which ask for a ban to be reinstated.
articles.lead_paragraph: After gasoline prices rose above $4 a gallon last summer, Republican cries of “drill, baby, drill” forced candidate Barack Obama into a rare retreat. Under pressure, he said he would support some expansion of offshore oil drilling, while still emphasizing conservation and renewable energy.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Seeking Return of Half of Its Bonuses
articles.snippet: Edward M. Liddy, the head of A.I.G., made an effort to tamp down populist anger at a Congressional hearing.
articles.abstract: Edward M. Liddy, the head of A.I.G., made an effort to tamp down populist anger at a Congressional hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two chief executives with much on the line in the furor over Wall Street bonuses  President Obama and Edward M. Liddy of the American International Group  made concerted efforts on Wednesday to tamp down the populist anger, but faced continued outrage on Capitol Hill and elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: I.B.M., Looking to Buy Sun, Sets Up a Software Strategy
articles.snippet: Analysts say Sun Microsystems’ strengths in software, systems design and research make it an attractive target.
articles.abstract: Analysts say Sun Microsystems’ strengths in software, systems design and research make it an attractive target.
articles.lead_paragraph: I.B.M.’s interest in acquiring the server computer maker Sun Microsystems for nearly $7 billion may seem at first to be a reversal of its recent efforts to move away from the hardware business.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Accountant for Madoff Is Arrested and Charged With Securities Fraud
articles.snippet: The accountant, working out of a tiny storefront office, provided auditing services to Bernard L. Madoff’s investment firm for more than a decade.
articles.abstract: The accountant, working out of a tiny storefront office, provided auditing services to Bernard L. Madoff’s investment firm for more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal investigation into Bernard L. Madoff’s $65 billion Ponzi scheme widened Wednesday with the arrest of an accountant who had audited Mr. Madoff’s investment advisory business for more than a decade.
articles.byline: By William K. Rashbaum and Diana B. Henriques
